Channel: #incident-200-sev3-pg-disk-drainage (C09DLE81CNA)
[2025-09-05 11:45:19] User: U099T22QHS9 (TS: 1757087119.072449)
URL: https://slack.com/archives/C09DLE81CNA/p1757087119072449
Message: update here.

tldr: wilson and I will experiment with following:
• adjust get_rows work_mem to ~36MB, for the get_rows query only
• do a hot-fix today
• closely monitor the free memory we have on the database box
• closely monitor the temp file size as well
• closely monitor query speed/performance improvement
next week:
• based on the results, might further increase it

rational:
• we have ~ 100GB free mem left
• the work_mem is per operation in a query
• we have ~100 active queries
• we assume each query has ~10 operations (we asked chatgpt for a real query, and chatgpt told us it contains 5 operations)
• so 100 * 10 * 32MB should take up to 32GB memory

if any of numbers seems off, please let us know.

thanks

Message: fwiw, I think the
EXPLAIN (ANALYZE, BUFFERS, VERBOSE)
  SELECT MAX(cells.updated_at)
  FROM cells
  WHERE cells.sheet_id = 'b63e38bf-b5e5-485b-95be-53cbf0b3567f'
  AND cells.tab_id = 'c700f126-e5fd-44ae-a8ec-27b83a62c58d'
  AND cells.versioned_column_id IN (
    '0257f67d-dac2-4a21-95a1-827a23b245e5'::uuid,
    '07c75a6a-e24d-4e8b-914c-4adef8031cae'::uuid,
    '071a271d-e60e-451e-8921-4471918bda2b'::uuid,
    '199f9b45-d9c2-4513-b784-f564c2b04b1e'::uuid,
    '253dbc1f-aa29-489e-a44a-ec54041cd878'::uuid,
    '27b14ac3-4a6e-4e00-8a7a-ddfb97a69c09'::uuid,
    '2c27ddb3-a3ac-4226-b094-d4c0a1fd6d6e'::uuid,
    '2f6bff24-7282-4ded-846a-07320dd0d6d6'::uuid,
    '3302362c-b7f9-43c5-8308-597c2447bac7'::uuid,
    '33f7c209-b5e9-48a4-9f98-8f3603be8e81'::uuid
  )

is not deterministic. if you try to run this again, you will likely see the ~200ms results.
so the buffer should not matter here.

but I agree with you that it must be some connection issue, otherwise it cannot explain the difference.

Message: <https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/database/understanding-autovacuum-in-amazon-rds-for-postgresql-environments/>

aws basically says:
• small table: more workers, less mem
• big tables: less worker, big mem.
we currently set autovacuum_work_mem to -1, which uses maintenance_work_mem, which is 4G.

still trying to calculate if this is enough
